newsitem.title: USA: Oracle says earnings more than double in quarter.
newsitem.headline: Oracle says earnings more than double in quarter.

text.p: Database software giant Oracle Corp. said Thursday its earnings more than doubled in its fiscal first quarter, partially because of a big charge in the year-ago quarter.
Earnings rose 110 percent to $113 million, or 17 cents a share, for its first fiscal quarter ended Aug. 31 from $54 million, or 8 cents a share, a year ago when it took a $34 million one-time charge.
The earnings were in line with Wall Street expectations.
Oracle's revenue growth, however, was slower than recent quarters as sales of software licenses slowed to 27 percent in a typical first quarter, summer slowdown, the company said.
Revenues rose 36 percent to $1.05 billion from $772 million.

"The first quarter is always a little bit of a struggle for us to to get started again. We just don't get the sales effort as other quarters of the year," said Jeff Henley, Oracle's chief financial officer. In the previous quarter, license sales grew 45 percent.
Oracle's incentive based sales compensation programme leads sales people to do an all out push in the fourth quarter, he said, and take it easier in the first quarter.
But he said the license sales growth was more than a year ago when in the same quarter they grew 25 percent.

Oracle reported its results after the close of the stock market Thursday. In after-hours trading following the report, its shares fell 25 cents from their $37.50 a share close. The stock had risen 87.5 cents in regular trading hours.
Oracle said license sales growth was led by its core database products, whose revenues grew 41 percent.
Revenues from services such as consulting, training and support rose 45 percent in the quarter, Oracle said.
The Redwood Shores, Calif,-based company said sales from all geographic regions of the world were solid, but sales from customers in North and South America were the strongest, growing 43 percent.
